author: Nicola Fifield
title: Hundreds of thousands of patients waiting a YEAR for life-changing surgery on NHS
text:
The NHS demo (Photo: Alamy) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
Almost 400,000 patients are ­languishing on hospital waiting lists of up to a YEAR for life-changing surgery after the crisis-hit NHS missed crucial targets to treat them. 
The situation is so dire some trusts have been forced to scrap non-emergency procedures for up to four months in a desperate bid to clear the backlog. 
Waiting times for surgery are at their worst level since the 18-week target was introduced five years ago. 
As tens of thousands filled the streets of London to march against Tory cuts crippling the NHS, we can ­reveal patients are being forced to ­endure agonising delays for ops such as spinal surgery, cataract removal and hip ­replacements. 
At the end of December last year 376,877 patients had been on the waiting list for 18 weeks or more – up from 275,539 in December 2010, the ­latest figures show. Read More A placard at the demo (Photo: Getty) 
Shockingly, 1,228 of these patients had been waiting more than 12 months. 
Waiting lists for planned NHS surgery have rocketed by 1.6 million over the past five years – from 2.1 million to 3.7 million. 
And the number of operations being cancelled at the last minute due to bed and staffing shortages is also soaring. 
In the last three months of last year 21,249 were postponed, up from 16,784 during the same period five years ago. 
Orthopaedic registrar Dr Rishi Dhir said: “I’ve heard of hospitals stopping doing any non-emergency operations for three or four months because they just can’t cope. This is happening right across the country.” Protesters in London (Photo: Getty) 
He added: “When patients are in pain, when they need an operation, it is heartbreaking to tell them their ­operation has been cancelled.” 
This financial year is set to be the first ever when the NHS pledge of treating 92 per cent of patients within 18 weeks of referral will not have been met in ANY month. In December the national ­average was 89.7 per cent. 
Katherine Murphy, chief executive of The Patients Association, said: “We have noticed a clear trend over recent years in the increasing time people are waiting for operations. 
"Not only can it be very stressful and painful when you are constantly waiting for surgery, but people can also fear losing further ­mobility and may find that they take longer to recover afterwards.” 
Richard Kerr, of the Royal College of Surgeons, warned: “Unless the NHS secures extra funding, waiting times, and the anxiety and discomfort they cause patients will only get worse.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
